measured_by: Cognitive Reflection Test – open-ended version / Cognitive Reflection Test – two-option multiple-choice version / Cognitive Reflection Test – four-option multiple-choice version
justification: “In a between-subjects design, the participants were randomly allocated to one of the three versions of the Cognitive Reflection Test…the original open-ended version, the two-option multiple-choice version or the four-option multiple-choice version of the test.”
“The participants assessed the logical validity of the conclusion of eight syllogisms…Correct responses were summed…to create a belief bias score.”
“We assessed paranormal beliefs across different domains…with the Revised Paranormal Belief Scale…The scale had excellent internal consistency.”

“We used five scenarios describing a game of chance in which the participants could draw a single ticket from one of two bowls…The ratings…were averaged…with higher values indicating a stronger tendency to neglect denominators.”
“We used the Actively Open-Minded Thinking‐Beliefs Scale to measure beliefs about open-mindedness…The scale had good internal consistency.”
“We used the Lipkus Numeracy Scale…The measure consists of 11 simple mathematical tasks…The participants’ correct answers were summed…so higher scores indicated higher numeracy.”
